The "Patient Right to Know Act" emphasizes the importance of open medical communications between healthcare providers and patients to ensure informed decision-making and quality care. It highlights the need for healthcare providers to exercise their best judgment without interference from health plans. The Patient Right to Know Act aims to establish a Federal standard protecting medical communications between healthcare providers and patients to ensure quality care. The Patient Right to Know Act establishes a Federal standard protecting medical communications between healthcare providers and patients to ensure quality care. SEC. 2 prohibits interference with certain medical communications. The Patient Right to Know Act prohibits contracts between health plans and providers from restricting medical communications with patients. Any such provisions in contracts are null and void, and no contract can include provisions that violate this rule. The Act allows health care providers to enforce mutually agreed upon terms and conditions in contracts, including participation in health plan programs to improve quality and utilization of services, as long as medical communications with patients are not restricted. The Act allows health care providers to enforce agreed-upon terms in contracts, including participation in health plan programs, without restricting medical communications with patients. States are responsible for enforcing the Act with health insurance issuers, while the Secretary can also enforce it starting in 1998. If a State fails to enforce the requirements of the Act with health insurance issuers, the Secretary will enforce them. Violations by health plans in such States may result in civil money penalties of up to $25,000 per violation. The Secretary of Labor will enforce the Act's requirements for health plans not regulated by states starting January 1, 1998. Civil money penalties may be imposed for violations, following specific procedures outlined in the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. The Act does not affect section 514 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. States can enforce medical communication protection laws as long as they are as or more protective than the federal requirements. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "health care provider," "health insurance issuer," and "health plan." A health care provider is someone licensed to provide health services, a health insurance issuer is defined by the Public Health Service Act, and a health plan includes group health plans and individual health insurance. The term "health insurance issuer" includes any health care coverage provided by a private or public entity. For employee welfare benefit plans, third party administrators are considered health insurance issuers. "Medical communication" refers to any communication between a health care provider and a patient, guardian, or legal representative. The term "medical communication" excludes any communication involving misrepresentation by a healthcare provider with a patient, guardian, or legal representative. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective upon enactment, with section 2(a)(3) taking effect 180 days later.
